_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Goglanian Bakeries, Inc

Fountain Inn, SC

Refrigeration System Process Description



Overview



This system is a two stage configuration utilizing computerized control for system operation.  There are a total of 6 screw compressors that handle the refrigeration loads.  There are 3low stage compressors and 3 high stage compressors acting either as low suction or high suction machines which is dictated by the load situations.  



There are two separate recirculator packages: one low temperature system operating at -38?F and a high temperature unit operating at +20?F.  The low temperature recirculator package feeds two spiral freezer evaporator units. The high temperature recirculator unit feeds 2 spiral cooling units. Hot gas defrost is employed for daily defrosting chores.



There are two evaporative condensers.  A Hansen auto-purger is also used to remove non-condensable materials.   





Process Description



Liquid Side



The liquid supply for the system starts at the Condensers.  The Condensers change superheated vapor discharged from the Compressors and remove a sufficient amount of heat such that the vapor changes to a liquid (condenses).  This condensed liquid leaves Condenser units EC-1 and EC-2 via 4-inch pipes and flows to the thermosyphon header and the Thermosyphon Receiver (V-1).  



The Thermosyphon Receiver supplies liquid to each screw compressor for cooling of the oil.  These oil coolers are mounted on the side of SCB 1-3 and SCH 1 screw compressor units.  The refrigerant in the oil coolers naturally recirculates to and from the Thermosyphon Receiver when there is a heat load. On SCH 2-3 liquid goes into liquid injection system.



The high-pressure liquid also leaves the Thermosyphon Receiver via a 4" line and feeds the Hansen auto-purger unit and High Temperature Recirculator (HPR).  The High Temperature Recirculator is operated at +20?F.  The liquid supply to V-2 is controlled by a float and solenoid.



The liquid from the Low Temp Reci

rculator (VPR-2) is pumped to air units. The liquid is also pumped to the Low Temperature Recirculator (V-1).  



The Low Temperature Recirculator is operated at -38?F.  A float and solenoid device controls the liquid supply to V-1.  The liquid from the Low Temperature Recirculator is pumped to the -38? F spiral freezer air units LT- 3 and LT -4.







Vapor Side



The Compressors remove the vapors from both the High Temperature Recirculator and the Low Temperature Recirculator vessels.  



Screw compressors: SCH 1-3 remove the vapors from the High Temperature Recirculator.  Screw Compressor SCB 1-3 removes vapors from the Low Temperature Recirculator.   Screw Compressors SCH-1 and SCH-2 are capable of being used to remove vapors from either the High Temperature Recirculator or the Low Temperature Recirculator.



The discharge of all the compressors, SCH-1 through SCH-3, is sent to the main discharge header, which feeds the Condenser units.  The Condensers change superheated vapor discharged from the Compressors and remove a sufficient amount of heat such that the vapor changes to a liquid (condenses).  



Additionally, as required, some of the superheated discharge vapors (hot gas) are diverted for use as a defrosting medium.  This defrost gas is sent to the Air Units.





Definitions



Thermosyphon System



A thermosyphon system is a means by which an uninterrupted supply of liquid refrigerant can be supplied to the compressor units.  This liquid utilizes a shell and tube or plate heat exchanger to keep the compressor's oil cooled and thus allowing the units to operate at the Manufacturer's recommended temperature.  



Liquid ammonia is supplied to the inlet of the heat exchanger.  When a heat load is applied to the heat exchanger, some of the liquid is vaporized.  This vapor-liquid mixture that is less dense than a pure liquid.  The denser liquid (supply) displaces the lighter vapor-liquid mixture thus pushing the mixture out of the heat exchanger and b

ack to the Thermosyphon Receiver.  This difference in density creates a natural circulation.





Two Stage Compression System



A two stage compressor system utilizes one or more compressors to pump the refrigerant vapor from the intermediate-pressure side to the high-pressure side of the refrigeration system.  Each compressor discharges directly to the condenser units via a common header. Booster compressors pump the refrigerant vapor from the low pressure side to the intermediate side of the refrigeration system.





Recirculator System



A recirculator system is a combination of a vessel, pumps, valves and other components used to feed a refrigeration circuit.  The pumps supply liquid to the various evaporators.  The outlet of the evaporators (consisting of liquid and vapor) is returned to the recirculator vessel for separation of the liquid and vapor.



The application can be either a low temp or high temp application. The liquid feed can be sub-cooled through an intercooler or fed directly from the receiver.





Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Goglanian Bakeries Inc. practices preventative maintenance procedures to ensure the mechanical integrity of the refrigeration system. By having these procedures in place, it allows for the detection of any variations or issues before any risk or accidental release could occur. In addition, selected employees have been trained in Emergency Response and have annual refreshers as required. 



Facility and Regulated Substances



Goglanian Bakeries Inc. is the producer of flour based baked goods and uses the regulated substance anhydrous ammonia to help cool in the production process.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Emergency Response Plan



1.) In case of an accidental release of ammonia gas, the Plant Emergency Response Plan will be initiated.



2.) Responsibility for the Emergency will be delegated through the Inside and Outside Coordinators



3.)  The Inside

Coordinator or his/her designee will insure, as applicable:

a. The location and extent of the leak/spill.

b. That the leak/spill be safely contained.

c. That all necessary information is conveyed to the Outside Coordinator.

d. That the building has been completely evacuated, if necessary.

e. That all appropriate valves and switches have been shut down or activated, whichever is applicable.

f. That only authorized and trained personnel are inside the building if evacuation is required.



4.) Employee Safety will be adhered to with the utilization of the following Personal Protective Equipment:

a. Rubber or Neoprene Gloves.

b. Tight fitting Safety Goggles.

c. Protective Rubber Boots.

d. Protective Rubber Slicker and/or Protective Rubber Pants and Jacket

e. Full Face Respirator with Ammonia Cartridges/Canisters (Green).

f. Self-Contained, Positive Pressure Breathing Apparatus.







5.) Ammonia Leak Plan of Action:



Upon discovery of an ammonia leak, the liquid line feeding the ammonia room will be turned off.  At first, this may be the valve on the manifold in the engine room, but the valve closest to the leak is the most important one to close.  When this valve is off, others should be turned back on.  The King Valve will not be turned off except for necessary work in the engine room itself.



The suction side of the leak will be inspected to determine if a valve there can be closed to isolate the affected area.  An inspection must be make to determine if a vacuum needs to be maintained to remove ammonia or to allow the balance of the ammonia to waste into the room.



Damage(s) will be repaired ASAP in order that refrigeration may be restored.  Broken parts will be saved for inspection by the insurance representative, if applicable.  Ventilation will be initiated simultaneously, being careful not to contaminate odor free storage areas.  Carbon Dioxide in cylinders will be placed in the area of the leak and valves will be carefully opened.  Enough ga

s will be used to neutralize the ammonia.  Sulphur Dioxide and Ozone are alternate neutralizing agents that should not be considered under any condition.  When water defrost units are the means of refrigeration then they will also be used as an absorbing means by having the water run over the coils.  Water from a hose may be directed upon the leak and a considerable portion of the escaping ammonia absorbed.



In addition, Goglanian Bakeries Inc. has reported their regulated substance to the local fire department, the LEPC, the state and the EPA as required.



AMMONIA MECHANICAL REFRIGERATION SYSTEM





Anhydrous Ammonia is not a cumulative poison.  It has a distinctive, pungent odor that even at low concentrations is detectable by most people.  Since ammonia is self-alarming, it serves as its own warning agent, so that a person will not voluntarily remain in concentrations that are hazardous.  Since ammonia gas is lighter that air, adequate ventilation is the best means of preventing an accumulation.



 Experience has shown that ammonia is extremely hard to ignite and under normal conditions is a very stable compound.  Under extremely limited conditions, ammonia can form ignitable mixtures with air and oxygen and should thus be treated with the utmost caution and respect.



THERE CAN NEVER BE A PLANT THAT IS TOO SAFE.



SAFETY SHOULD BE A WAY OF LIFE.







TABLE 7.

    On short exposure..............................150-200 ppm

    Effect on short exposure.......................400-700 ppm

ss than 1/2 hour

    Exposure may be fatal.......................2000-3000 ppm

    Asphyxia, rapidly fatal....................5000-10000 ppm

FIRST AID FOR AMMONIA GASING



6.) Move affected person(s) to fresh air immediately.



7.) Summon First Aid/CPR qualified personnel or call 911 immediately.



8.) Remove clothing if splashed with liquid or impregnated with concentrated vapor.



9.) Keep the patient still and warmly wrapped in blankets.



10.) If conscious and mouth is not burned, give hot sweet tea or coffee.



11.) Oxygen may be administered by qualified personnel when directed to do so by competent medical authority.



12.) If breathing stops, begin CPR immediately.





LIQUID SPLASHES OR CONCENTRATED VAPOR IN THE EYES.



1.) Irrigate the eyes immediately with water and continue for at least thirty (30) minutes.  (Eye wash stations, emergency showers or any other source of water, such as employee showers or water hoses may be used).



2.) Summon First Aid/CPR qualified personnel or call 911 immediately.







SKIN BURNS FROM SPLASHES OR CONCENTRATED VAPOR



1.) Wash immediately with large quantities of water and continue for at least fifteen (15) minutes.  Remove all clothing while washing.  (An emergency shower or any other source of water, such as employee showers or water hoses may be used)



2.) Summon First Aid/CPR qualified personnel or call 911 immediately.



3.) After washing, apply wet compresses to affect body parts until medical help arrives.





Note:  Keep an irrigation bottle readily available





5 Year Accident History



Goglanian Bakeries Inc. has not had an accident to report in the last 5 years.
